pageLinks.Main-content-1: For centuries, architects, engineers, artists of different nationalities created in Belarus. Italians, Flemings, French, Germans, Belgians, Poles, Lithuanians, Russians worked here. In turn, immigrants from Belarus, including builders, craftsmen working in Russia and in many countries of Western Europe, gained fame there.
pageLinks.Main-content-2: Until the 9th century. monumental architecture was at the initial stage of development and is represented by burial mounds and pagan temples.
pageLinks.Main-content-3: IX-XI centuries. characterized by the development of feudal relations, the introduction of Christianity, the flourishing of all areas of culture. Princely mansions, churches and monasteries appear.
pageLinks.Main-content-4: In the XII-XIII centuries. on the territory of modern Belarus there are several specific principalities. Monumental monuments of that time: in Polotsk - the Savior-Efrosinievsky Cathedral (XII century), in Vitebsk - Annunciation Church (XII century), Grodno - Borisoglebskaya, or Kolozha Church (XII century), Kamenets - Belaya Vezha (XIII century).
pageLinks.Main-content-5: Frequent wars that took place on the territory of Belarus had a significant impact on the development of urban planning and architecture. Much attention was paid at that time to the construction of developed city fortifications, fortresses, castles, defense temples. The cult architecture of the defense type is most complete represented by temples in Synkovichi (XV century) and Murovanka (early XVI century). They are characterized by a compact massive volume with a high gable roof and the presence of four or two corner towers with loopholes.
pageLinks.Main-content-6: Castles of the XIV-XVI centuries. have the features of Gothic architecture: a kind of masonry, overlap in the form of lancet cross vaults or arches with ribs, high windows and lancet shaped doors. Cult architecture the defense type is most fully represented by temples in Synkovichi (XV century) and Murovanka (early XVI century). They are characterized by a compact massive volume with a high gable roof and the presence of four or two corner towers with loopholes.
pageLinks.Main-content-7: In the of the 16th century from Western Europe, Belarus began to penetrate the ideas of reformation and humanism, which led to the establishment of the principles of Renaissance art. First, elements of the Renaissance penetrated into architecture (Smorgon) , and then the baroque (Nesvizh).
pageLinks.Main-content-8: The main artistic direction in the architecture of XVII and the first three quarters of the XVIII century. was baroque. The architecture of the early churches is closely connected with the influence of the Italian art school, but from the second half of the XVII century. monuments with local features appear.
pageLinks.Main-content-9: From the second half of the 18th century. baroque was replaced by classicism, which finally became firmly established at the end of the 18th century. Simplifications of lines, volumes, details are noted in the buildings, simple and calm forms appear not devoid of the sophistication inherent in Baroque architecture.
pageLinks.Main-content-10: The architecture of the of the second half of the 19th - beginning of the 20th centuries. was a turning point in the history of architecture of Belarus. It is characterized by fundamental changes in construction equipment, the struggle and the change of a number of artistic styles.
pageLinks.Main-content-11: Modern architecture of Belarus relies heavily on architectural and artistic developments of past centuries, a variety of styles and directions.

pageLinks.footerCreatedBy: Created by the first group students
pageLinks.teamDescriptionAlexKlim: Team lead of our project. Managed all the team actions during the whole development process: from the basic application structure implementation with its technical part and up to checking and reviewing literally all the new pull requests. And also implemented complex animations, made translations and created content.
pageLinks.teamDescriptionVladimirDrachuk: The best of us. Got in RSSchool TOP. Made the most part of the whole work: literally every single page of the application was created due to Vladimir’s contribution. He always found right solutions for any pending task. He willingly helped every team member sparing neither energy nor time and working not just at the daytime, but even at night.
pageLinks.teamDescriptionPavelLeskavets: The key figure of our project. The most experienced man in our team. He knew exactly what to do from the very beginning and offered smart and right solutions. He implemented the most complex tasks in the application: almost every extra scope feature and also different libraries were implemented due to Pavel’s contribution.
pageLinks.teamDescriptionYuliyaTakmakova: Chief designer of our project. Unlike other teams, we completely developed the design by ourselves: no templates or turnkey solutions were used, and everything was made manually. Beautiful design is the base for success of any application!
pageLinks.teamDescriptionOleksandrKlymenko: The most intelligent man in our team. True professional. Acts more and talks less: quickly got what he should do and asking no redundant questions got down to business. He solved all the problems by himself. Cope with the implementation of his task fast of all.
pageLinks.teamDescriptionDmitriLobachevski: The most reliable man in our team. He responsibly started his work and easily implemented his part of the task by himself. Dmitri did his work so thoroughly that the module he was developing is the only one in our application that doesn’t even need to be fixed or improved.
pageLinks.portalInfo: Any portal usually has pages on a certain topic or a special field. Culture portals can be dedicated to one or even more cultural projects. But nevertheless, unlike huge culture portals which are made to coordinate and manage the actions of theirs authors, who write articles and create content for the portal, our culture portal is focused on the visitor, providing an overall overview of the Belarusian architecture in general and contains summarized information about Belarusian architects.
pageLinks.styleguideWelcome: Welcome to the styleguide of our
pageLinks.styleguideDescription: Here you can find all the styles used in our project

ananich.name: Yuri Stepanovich Ananich
ananich.vita: Belarusian architect. Member of the Belarusian Union of Architects.
ananich.timeline1: He graduated from the architectural department of the Belarusian State Polytechnic Institute (now BNTU) with a degree in urban planning.
ananich.timeline2: After completing his studies, he worked for thirty years at RUE “Institute Belgosproekt”.
ananich.timeline3: Participated in the design of three high-rise buildings, which the Russian company Itera planned to build in addition to the residential skyscraper Parus in the framework of the multifunctional complex “Business Center on ul. M. Tanka.
ananich.timeline4: Tragically died at the railway station Ptich, Minsk region
ananich.worktitle1: Residential complex of the Russian Embassy in Belarus
ananich.worktitle2: Head office of BSB Bank on Zaslavskaya Street in Minsk
ananich.worktitle3: Building of branch № 511 of the JSSB Belarusbank
ananich.worktitle4: Residential complex of the Russian Embassy
ananich.worktitle5: Reconstruction of the building of the National Bank of Belarus

dzuzeppe.name: Giuseppe de Sacco
dzuzeppe.vita: One of the largest architects of developed baroque and classicism working in the territory of modern Belarus
dzuzeppe.timeline1: Giuseppe de Sacco was invited to Warsaw, where he was engaged in the artistic hearse (áastrum doloris) of Queen Maria Leschinska and the project of rebuilding the church of St. John.
dzuzeppe.timeline2: He became the architect of the Skarbovaya Commission of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania
dzuzeppe.timeline3: Giuseppe de Sacco completed a number of orders from local magnates, having designed several well-known palace and park ensembles and city residences.

karako.name: Victor Karako
karako.vita: Belarusian Architect, Member of the Board of the Belarusian Union of Architects
karako.timeline1: Studied at the Department of Architecture of the Belarusian Polytechnic Institute
karako.timeline2: He worked as an architect, senior architect, chief architect of projects, and head of a workshop at BELGOSPROEKT.
karako.timeline3: Head of the group of architects, chief architect of projects, head of the workshop BelNIIPgradostroitelstvo
karako.timeline4: He became the winner of the Leninsky Komsomol Prize of Belarus in the field of architecture for the design of the Palace of Youth in Novopolotsk.
karako.worktitle3: Reconstruction of the bank building along Zaslavskaya Street 10

levin.name: Leonid Mendelevich Levin
levin.vita: Honored Architect of the Republic of Belarus.
levin.timeline1: Studying at the Belarusian Polytechnic Institute.
levin.timeline2: Work at the Minskproject Institute (from the architect to the head of the Minsk Construction Center Workshop).
levin.timeline3: Participation in the creation of the park. 50th anniversary of Soviet power.
levin.timeline4: Participation in the creation of the exhibition pavilion VDNH BSSR in Minsk.
levin.timeline5: As part of the group of authors, he was awarded the Lenin Prize for the memorial complex of 1968-1969. Khatyn.

paolo.name: Paolo Antonio Domenico Fontana
paolo.vita: Italian architect who worked in the Commonwealth
paolo.timeline1: He married the first wife of Marianne Sufchinskaya
paolo.timeline2: He received the rank of lieutenant of artillery of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania
paolo.timeline3: He returned to Italy, but next year he signed a new contract for the service at the court of Prince Paul Karl Sangushko, now in Izyaslav
paolo.timeline4: After the death of his wife, married again with Teresa Romironi

langbard.name: Iosif Langbard
langbard.vita: Belarusian Soviet architect, Honored Art Worker of the Belarusian SSR
langbard.timeline1: He moved to St. Petersburg, where he successfully passed the exams at the Higher Art School at the Imperial Academy of Arts at the Faculty of Architecture
langbard.timeline2: The architectural project of Langbard, among forty-seven works of other authors, participated in the competition of projects of the Palace of Labor in Moscow - the main public building of the USSR
langbard.timeline3: Won All-Union Competition for the best project of the House of Government of the Belarusian SSR
langbard.timeline4: Langbard completed a competitive project of a three-hundred apartment building for workers of the Red Triangle plant in Leningrad
langbard.timeline5: Creativity of the architect received worldwide recognition, the year Joseph Langbard won the Grand Prix of the World Exhibition in Paris
langbard.worktitle1: Government House of the Republic of Belarus

shabunevsky.name: Stanislav Shabunevsky
shabunevsky.vita: Belarusian architect, author of a significant part of the development of Gomel at the beginning of the XX century. Honorary citizen of Gomel
shabunevsky.timeline1: He graduated from the Slutsk gymnasium and entered the St. Petersburg Institute of Civil Engineers, taking a course in architecture with academician S. Schreter.
shabunevsky.timeline2: He served in Gomel as a city architect
shabunevsky.timeline3: He receives the civil rank of college assessor and is part of the city administration. Later he also went to the zemstvo according to the Polish Curia.
shabunevsky.timeline4: He was mobilized in the Red Army, served in the military field construction, whose head of department became in 1921
shabunevsky.timeline5: Appointed provincial, and in 1927, after administrative transformation - district engineer. From October 1929, S. Shabunevsky worked as head of the construction control department, and from January 1 to February 21, 1931, under the Gomel City Council
shabunevsky.timeline6: By a decree of an extrajudicial body, S. D. Shabunevsky was sentenced and sentenced to 10 years of forced labor (Bear Mountain, Belomorkanal), from where he did not return.
shabunevsky.worktitle2: Oryol Commercial Bank on the corner of Rumyantsevskaya and Irininskaya streets in Gomel
shabunevsky.worktitle3: The building of the former Vilnius Commercial Bank
shabunevsky.worktitle4: The former home of Gomel doctor N. I. Alexandrov on the street. Irininskaya 11 in Gomel
shabunevsky.worktitle5: One of the buildings of the Zemstvo hospital on Komissarova street 27, Gomel

parusnikov.name: Mikhail Parusnikov
parusnikov.vita: Soviet architect, full member of the Academy of Architecture of the USSR, academician of the Academy of Sciences of the BSSR, Laureate of the State Prize of the Belarusian SSR
parusnikov.timeline1: Studied at the Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture
parusnikov.timeline2: Worked in architectural and design organizations in Moscow and at the same time taught at the Moscow Architectural Institute
parusnikov.timeline3: Senior Researcher, USSR Academy of Architecture
parusnikov.timeline4: Head of the architectural and design workshops of the Committee for Architecture of the USSR
parusnikov.timeline5: He published a number of scientific works on the theory and history of architecture, including: “On the principles of integrated serial design of residential buildings”
parusnikov.worktitle1: Administrative building - KGB of Belarus, the first building on the main street of the city
parusnikov.worktitle2: National Bank of the Republic of Belarus
parusnikov.worktitle3: Residential buildings and a bridge over the Svisloch River on Nemiga in Minsk
parusnikov.worktitle4: House with an arch on Red Square in Moscow

alexKlim.name: Alexey Klimovskoy
alexKlim.feature3: main module, navigation and routing, 404 page

min-scope.title: Min Scope
min-scope.item1: Main page + page with a list of authors + author's page (only pages with content without widgets)
min-scope.item2: Page with team members + page with worklog
min-scope.item3: Page with list of authors contains search widget

normal-scope.title: Normal Scope
normal-scope.item8: Design (typography, icons, colors, links + buttons + input, ui components are styled)

extra-scope.title: Extra Scope
extra-scope.item3: Contentful / netlify cms / other cms is used for content management
extra-scope.item6: Storybook/angularplayground/compodoc/other angulaer styleguide/documentation tool usage for the page with stylesq

worklog.title: Self-evaluation
worklog.worklog-difficulties: What are the main challenges faced during the application development process?
worklog.difficulty1: Definitely the design. Technical part of the application development is a pretty clear thing. But the application design is all about creativity. We didn’t use any template and we did all the drawings manually ourselves.
worklog.difficulty2: Collecting and processing data about the architects. It can seem pretty strange, but gathering all the information piece-by-piece appeared to be a not quite simple task.
worklog.difficulty3: Some extra scope features. For example, CMS and Scully appeared to be not quite simple things. Understanding the mechanism of its functionality can take lots of time and effort.
